content.description: Route directly next to Timbarb, essentially on the arete. Start on the right edge of the buttress and climb up the black broken rock to reach a small overhang on the right edge. Pull hard to turn overhang to right facing edge; fight the barn door. past this crux, it is pretty relaxed. Follow the obvious flake to the ledge with a tree. From there follow the arete from here, which is protected with one bolt 5 down and to the right from the anchor. Note: Some of the rock here is severely fractured and loose.
content.protection: Standard rack. Micro nuts can protect the final 20' arete portion but are not necessary as there is a bolt there.

content.description: Same start as Copperhead at the blocky corner, though the thin seam on the face provides an alternate route to the first horizontal.  Either way, get some good gear in at the horizontals then run it out up the face towards the shallow right facing flake.  Blow it here and you might hit the ground.  After gaining the ledge, make a few thin moves to continue straight up the face on the right of the sapling, placing marginal pro in the horizontal (ledge fall potential). Alternatively, finish up the 5" crack to the two bolt anchor shared with Copperhead.
content.protection: Small to medium cams (nothing bigger than 1"), nuts, tricams.

content.description: The slab route with 4 glue-in bolts: two at the bottom to an easy trad section, then two more at the top. The movements are elegant for both slabs and are sadly interrupted by a near nothing trad climb.
content.protection: #2 and #3 BD cam; 4 bolts and hooks at top
content.location: Obvious mixed route climber's left to Copperhead.

content.description: A dihedral near the end of the wall; pretty obvious. Has a tree midway up that is perfect natural protection.

Start on the blackend rock 8-10 feet right of the arete. Climb the fractured rock using every technique imaginable. A bolt has been added midway to protect what is believed the crux section. Travel lightly on this route as nearly everything is fragile.
content.protection: Standard rack; 1 bolt and 2 ovals at the top.

content.description: Short but varied climb.  Start at lower right side of slab and work up the blocky corner and thin crack to a horizontal.  Traverse left under a 2-3' block to a ledge.  Continue up left facing corner to a ledge, then up a short offwidth crack to the anchor.  The route gets its name from the snakes that inhabit the cracks.
content.protection: Thin to medium nuts, tricams, cams in finger to hands size, plus a #5 Camalot to protect the offwidth.  Two bolt anchor.

content.description: Easy crack system that can be easily escaped both right and left.
content.protection: Handsize cams or passive; hooks at top
content.location: Left of the mixed climb by ~8ft

content.description: There are several routes on the slab emblazoned with Tim's love of Barb.
